case_title: Muhammad Muti-Ur-Rehman, Lahore vs Commissioner Inland Revenue, Rto, Lahore
reference_no_or_id: MA(Rect.) No.242/LB of 2022 in I.T.A. No.3117/LB of 2020

accussed_details.name: Muhammad Muti-Ur-Rehman
allegation: Failure to disclose plot in wealth statement
Disputed base income assessment under section 122(5A) of Income Tax Ordinance, 2001

complaint_summary: The appellant challenged the CIR(A)'s findings and the Tribunal's earlier decision regarding the assessment of income and alleged forgery of a property agreement.
investigation_summary: The appellant claimed the property was sold on 14.03.2014 and provided transfer documentation. The CIR(A) upheld the findings of the OIR, which were contested by the appellant as being based on forged evidence.
judgment_summary: The Tribunal acknowledged mistakes in its earlier order, including failure to adjudicate legal grounds and reliance on CIR(A)'s findings without independent analysis. The case was recalled for fresh hearing and disposal.
Decision_or_verdict: Order recalled; case fixed for fresh hearing.
legal_arguments: Rectification of mistakes under section 221 of Income Tax Ordinance, 2001
Tribunal's failure to adjudicate legal issues independently

assets.details: Sold on 14.03.2014 to Mr. Latif Hakeem as per transfer letter Sr. No. 40127 dated 10.04.2014

witnesses.name: Mr. Saadullah Khan
witnesses.role: Producer of disputed agreement to sell

witness_statement.Mr. Saadullah Khan: Produced agreement to sell dated 21.11.2013, alleged to be forged.

maxims.Binding Precedents: Judicial decisions of higher courts must be followed by subordinate judicial forums.

legal_terms.Rectification: Correction of errors apparent on the face of the record.

words_and_phrases.Mistake Apparent from Record: Errors of law or fact visible in the order or record.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around rectification of errors in a tax assessment dispute. The appellant challenged the findings of CIR(A) and the Tribunal's earlier order, citing reliance on forged evidence and failure to adjudicate legal issues independently. The Tribunal acknowledged errors and recalled its order for fresh hearing.
